title: Ohm's Law Experiment
description: Explore the fundamental relationship between voltage, current, and resistance in electrical circuits
objectives: Understand Ohm's Law: V = I × R
Learn to use ammeters and voltmeters correctly
Measure voltage, current, and resistance in circuits
Analyze the relationship between electrical quantities
Apply Ohm's Law to solve circuit problems

keyTerms.definition: The electrical potential difference between two points, measured in Volts (V)
The rate of flow of electric charge, measured in Amperes (A)
The opposition to current flow in a conductor, measured in Ohms (Ω)
The fundamental relationship: Voltage = Current × Resistance (V = I × R)
An instrument used to measure electric current, connected in series with the circuit
An instrument used to measure voltage, connected in parallel across components
A circuit where components are connected end-to-end, forming a single path for current
A circuit where components are connected across common points, providing multiple paths for current

safetyConsiderations: Always disconnect power before making circuit connections or changes
Start with low voltages (1-5V) and gradually increase
Check polarity before connecting meters to avoid damage
Never exceed the maximum ratings of components
Avoid touching exposed wires when the circuit is energized
Use insulated tools and probes when working with circuits
Monitor components for signs of overheating
Have a fire extinguisher nearby when working with electrical equipment
Ensure proper ventilation in the laboratory

supplies.description: Insulated copper wires with alligator clips

procedure.setup: Assemble components on a clean, dry work surface. Verify all equipment is functioning properly before starting.

steps.title: Initial Setup
instructions: Set the power supply to 0V and ensure it's off
Connect the resistor in series with the ammeter
Connect the voltmeter in parallel across the resistor

steps.title: First Measurement
instructions: Close the switch to complete the circuit

steps.title: Varying Resistance
instructions: Set voltage to a constant value (e.g., 6V)

power.formula: P = V × I = I² × R = V² / R

observations.voltageConstant: When resistance is constant, current increases linearly with voltage (direct proportionality)
observations.resistanceConstant: When voltage is constant, current decreases as resistance increases (inverse proportionality)
observations.graphVvsI: The V-I graph is a straight line passing through origin, with slope = R
observations.graphIvs1R: The I vs 1/R graph is a straight line with slope = V

conclusion.mainFinding: Ohm's Law (V = I × R) accurately describes the relationship between voltage, current, and resistance in simple circuits. Current is directly proportional to voltage and inversely proportional to resistance.
evidence: Linear V-I graph confirms direct proportionality between voltage and current
Calculated resistance values match nominal resistor values
Inverse relationship between current and resistance verified
All measurements follow the equation V = I × R within experimental error
conclusion.implications: Understanding Ohm's Law is fundamental for circuit design, troubleshooting, and analysis in electronics and electrical engineering

realWorldApplications.description: Engineers use Ohm's Law to calculate appropriate resistor values for LEDs, transistors, and integrated circuits
realWorldApplications.example: Selecting a 330Ω resistor to limit current through a 2V LED powered by a 5V source

realWorldApplications.description: Calculating voltage drops in transmission lines and house wiring
realWorldApplications.example: Determining wire gauge needed to minimize voltage loss over distance

realWorldApplications.description: Technicians use Ohm's Law to diagnose circuit faults by measuring voltages and currents
realWorldApplications.example: Identifying a short circuit by measuring abnormally high current

realWorldApplications.description: Designing fuses and circuit breakers based on maximum safe currents
realWorldApplications.example: A 15A household circuit breaker protects against overload

realWorldApplications.description: Estimating how long a battery will last given load resistance
realWorldApplications.example: Calculating runtime of a 1000mAh battery powering a 50Ω load

realWorldApplications.description: Many sensors work by changing resistance, which affects current according to Ohm's Law

quizQuestions.question: What is the correct formula for Ohm's Law?
quizQuestions.explanation: Ohm's Law states that Voltage (V) equals Current (I) multiplied by Resistance (R). This can be rearranged to find any unknown quantity: I = V/R or R = V/I.

quizQuestions.question: If voltage stays constant, how does current change when resistance increases?
quizQuestions.explanation: From I = V/R, we see that current is inversely proportional to resistance. When R increases, I decreases (and vice versa) if V remains constant.

quizQuestions.question: If you double the voltage across a resistor, what happens to the current?
quizQuestions.explanation: Current is directly proportional to voltage (I = V/R). Doubling the voltage doubles the current if resistance remains constant.

quizQuestions.question: A circuit has a 12V battery and a 4Ω resistor. What is the current?
How should an ammeter be connected in a circuit?
quizQuestions.explanation: An ammeter must be connected in series so that all the current flows through it. Connecting in parallel would create a short circuit and damage the meter.

extensions.description: Test materials like light bulbs and diodes that don't follow Ohm's Law
Compare how Ohm's Law applies to series and parallel circuit configurations
Investigate how resistance changes with temperature and affects current
Use Ohm's Law to calculate power dissipation (P = V × I) in resistors
Use software like CircuitJS or TINA to simulate complex circuits and verify Ohm's Law

learningOutcomes: Students can state and apply Ohm's Law to solve circuit problems
Students understand the relationships between voltage, current, and resistance
Students can correctly use ammeters and voltmeters in circuits
Students can interpret V-I graphs and determine resistance from slopes
Students recognize when Ohm's Law applies and when it doesn't
Students can troubleshoot simple circuit problems using measurements
